summary: The document is a classified communication detailing interactions between a U.S. professor and a KGB official, Nikonov, during the week of 3-9 November 1991. It discusses Nikonov's background, his relationship with the KGB director Bakatin, and his assignments, including reviewing KGB files on Lee Harvey Oswald and investigating the fate of Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg. The document also provides biographical information on the U.S. professor involved.
key_findings: Nikonov, a deputy to KGB director Bakatin, was a close friend of Bakatin and played a role in restructuring the KGB post the August 1991 coup attempt.
Nikonov reviewed KGB files on Lee Harvey Oswald and concluded Oswald was never a KGB agent, describing him as uncontrollable and a poor shot.
Nikonov investigated the fate of Raoul Wallenberg, finding partial evidence suggesting Wallenberg was executed in 1947, though no conclusive proof was found.
The U.S. professor, a Fulbright scholar, had a long-standing relationship with Nikonov and provided information on Nikonov and other contacts to U.S. officials.
